subjects.name: Python Complete Course
subjects.description: Master Python variables and data types

topics.title: Variables and Data Types
topics.description: Understanding Python variables, data types, type conversion, and type checking

contents.title: Variables in Python
contents.content:
Variables are containers for storing data values. Python has no command for declaring a variable - it's created when you assign a value.

Key Points:
‚Ä¢ No declaration needed (unlike Java/C++)
‚Ä¢ No type specification required
‚Ä¢ Type is determined automatically
‚Ä¢ Can change type after assignment
‚Ä¢ Use descriptive names
‚Ä¢ Follow naming conventions

Variable Assignment:
‚Ä¢ Use = operator
‚Ä¢ Variable name on left, value on right
‚Ä¢ Can assign multiple variables at once
‚Ä¢ Can assign same value to multiple variables

Variable Naming Rules:
‚Ä¢ Start with letter or underscore
‚Ä¢ Can contain letters, numbers, underscores
‚Ä¢ Case-sensitive (age ‚â† Age)
‚Ä¢ Cannot use Python keywords
‚Ä¢ Use snake_case for variables

Best Practices:
‚Ä¢ Use meaningful names (user_age not x)
‚Ä¢ Avoid single letters (except in loops)
‚Ä¢ Use lowercase for variables
‚Ä¢ Use UPPERCASE for constants
‚Ä¢ Don't use Python built-in names

contents.title: Creating Variables
contents.content:
# Simple variable assignment
name = 'Raj Sharma'
age = 25
height = 5.9
is_student = True

print(name)      # Raj Sharma
print(age)       # 25
print(height)    # 5.9
print(is_student)  # True

# Multiple assignment
x, y, z = 10, 20, 30
print(x, y, z)  # 10 20 30

# Same value to multiple variables
a = b = c = 100
print(a, b, c)  # 100 100 100

# Swapping variables
x = 5
y = 10
x, y = y, x  # Swap
print(x, y)  # 10 5

# Variable reassignment
count = 10
print(count)  # 10
count = 20
print(count)  # 20

# Changing type
value = 100      # int
value = 'Hello'  # now string
value = 3.14     # now float

# Constants (by convention, not enforced)
PI = 3.14159
MAX_SIZE = 1000
API_KEY = 'abc123'

# Unpacking
fruits = ['Apple', 'Banana', 'Mango']
first, second, third = fruits
print(first)   # Apple
print(second)  # Banana

examples.title: Variable Naming Examples
examples.code:
# Good variable names
user_name = 'Priya'
user_age = 22
total_price = 999.99
is_active = True
item_count = 5

# Bad variable names (but valid)
x = 'Priya'  # Not descriptive
a = 22       # What is 'a'?
tp = 999.99  # Unclear abbreviation

# Constants
MAX_LOGIN_ATTEMPTS = 3
DEFAULT_TIMEOUT = 30
API_URL = 'https://api.example.com'

# Private variables (convention)
_internal_value = 100
_private_key = 'secret'

# Invalid names (will cause error)
# 2name = 'Error'  # Can't start with number
# my-name = 'Error'  # Can't use hyphen
# for = 'Error'  # Can't use keyword
examples.explanation: Use descriptive names that explain what the variable stores. Follow Python naming conventions for better code readability.

contents.title: Python Data Types
contents.content:
Python has several built-in data types to store different kinds of information.

Numeric Types:
‚Ä¢ int: Whole numbers (1, 42, -10, 1000000)
‚Ä¢ float: Decimal numbers (3.14, -0.5, 2.0)
‚Ä¢ complex: Complex numbers (3+4j)

Sequence Types:
‚Ä¢ str: Text/strings ('hello', "world")
‚Ä¢ list: Ordered, mutable collection [1, 2, 3]
‚Ä¢ tuple: Ordered, immutable collection (1, 2, 3)

Mapping Type:
‚Ä¢ dict: Key-value pairs {'name': 'Raj', 'age': 25}

Set Types:
‚Ä¢ set: Unordered, unique elements {1, 2, 3}
‚Ä¢ frozenset: Immutable set

Boolean Type:
‚Ä¢ bool: True or False

Binary Types:
‚Ä¢ bytes: Immutable byte sequence
‚Ä¢ bytearray: Mutable byte sequence

None Type:
‚Ä¢ None: Represents absence of value

Type Characteristics:
‚Ä¢ Mutable: Can be changed (list, dict, set)
‚Ä¢ Immutable: Cannot be changed (int, float, str, tuple)

contents.title: Working with Data Types
contents.content:
# Integer (int)
age = 25
count = 100
negative = -50
large_number = 1000000

print(type(age))  # <class 'int'>

# Float
price = 99.99
pi = 3.14159
temperature = -5.5
scientific = 2.5e3  # 2500.0

print(type(price))  # <class 'float'>

# String (str)
name = 'Raj Sharma'
city = "Mumbai"
multiline = '''This is
a multiline
string'''

print(type(name))  # <class 'str'>

# Boolean (bool)
is_active = True
has_permission = False

print(type(is_active))  # <class 'bool'>

# List (mutable)
fruits = ['Apple', 'Banana', 'Mango']
numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
mixed = [1, 'Hello', 3.14, True]

print(type(fruits))  # <class 'list'>

# Tuple (immutable)
coordinates = (10, 20)
colors = ('red', 'green', 'blue')

print(type(coordinates))  # <class 'tuple'>

# Dictionary (dict)
person = {
    'name': 'Priya',
    'age': 22,
    'city': 'Delhi'
}

print(type(person))  # <class 'dict'>

# Set (unique elements)
unique_numbers = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}
fruits_set = {'apple', 'banana', 'mango'}

print(type(unique_numbers))  # <class 'set'>

# None
result = None
print(type(result))  # <class 'NoneType'>

examples.title: Type Checking
examples.code:
# Check type using type()
age = 25
print(type(age))  # <class 'int'>

name = 'Raj'
print(type(name))  # <class 'str'>

# Check if variable is of specific type
age = 25
print(isinstance(age, int))     # True
print(isinstance(age, str))     # False

fruits = ['apple', 'banana']
print(isinstance(fruits, list))  # True
print(isinstance(fruits, tuple)) # False

# Check multiple types
value = 3.14
print(isinstance(value, (int, float)))  # True

# Practical use
def process_data(data):
    if isinstance(data, str):
        print('Processing string:', data.upper())
    elif isinstance(data, int):
        print('Processing number:', data * 2)
    elif isinstance(data, list):
        print('Processing list:', len(data), 'items')

process_data('hello')  # Processing string: HELLO
process_data(10)       # Processing number: 20
process_data([1,2,3])  # Processing list: 3 items
examples.explanation: Use type() to get the type of a variable and isinstance() to check if a variable is of a specific type.

examples.title: Type Conversion (Casting)
examples.code:
# String to Integer
age_str = '25'
age_int = int(age_str)
print(age_int)       # 25
print(type(age_int)) # <class 'int'>

# String to Float
price_str = '99.99'
price_float = float(price_str)
print(price_float)  # 99.99

# Integer to String
count = 100
count_str = str(count)
print(count_str)       # '100'
print(type(count_str)) # <class 'str'>

# Float to Integer (truncates decimal)
price = 99.99
price_int = int(price)
print(price_int)  # 99 (not 100!)

# String to Boolean
print(bool('Hello'))  # True (non-empty string)
print(bool(''))       # False (empty string)
print(bool(0))        # False
print(bool(1))        # True

# List to Tuple
fruits_list = ['apple', 'banana']
fruits_tuple = tuple(fruits_list)
print(fruits_tuple)  # ('apple', 'banana')

# Tuple to List
colors_tuple = ('red', 'green')
colors_list = list(colors_tuple)
print(colors_list)  # ['red', 'green']

# String to List
text = 'Hello'
chars = list(text)
print(chars)  # ['H', 'e', 'l', 'l', 'o']

# Handling conversion errors
try:
    num = int('abc')  # ValueError
except ValueError:
    print('Cannot convert to integer!')
examples.explanation: Type conversion (casting) allows you to convert one data type to another. Use int(), float(), str(), bool(), list(), tuple() functions.
